Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Additive Manufacturing of Radio Frequency and Microwave Components from a Highly Conductive 3D Printing Filament
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project will enable the rapid prototyping and manufacturing of radio frequency (RF) components with 3D printing, and thereby reduce component cost, weight, and turnaround time. The global RF components market is expected to reach $17.54 billion by 2022, but fabrication techniques for commercial RF components have seen little innovation. Conventional RF manufacturing techniques, such machining and photolithography, are accurate and reliable, but they are also expensive, time-consuming and produce unnecessary waste. 3D printing enables fast and accurate manufacturing of custom components, as well as the creation of extremely complex geometries at low-cost for improved component performance. 3D printing can also enable users to design components to fit the design space available, removing the necessity of designing technology around commercially available parts, a critical feature in space and weight-sensitive aerospace applications. However, the materials available to 3D printing are mostly limited to non-conducting polymers. By creating a highly conductive 3D printing material, and testing the properties of RF components made with this filament, this project will make it possible to rapidly prototype and produce custom RF components, thereby accelerating research and improving the competitiveness of RF component manufacturing in the U.S.

This STTR proposal will create a highly conductive (>2×10^5 S m-1) polymer filament that can be used with low-cost fused deposition modeling 3D printers to create a variety of high-value RF components. The filament will be engineered to print reliably, and retain its conductivity and mechanical integrity to temperatures of ~150 °C. To achieve these goals, the proposed work will determine the relationship between conductivity, the loading of conductive filler, the shape of the conductive filler, the filament mechanical properties, and the viscosity of the filament at printing temperatures. New methods will be developed to prevent oxidation of the conductive filler at elevated temperatures. A novel conductive filler will be developed to achieve these performance specifications at low cost. Concurrent with these material development efforts, novel RF components will be designed, simulated, and printed in order to build a comprehensive database with detailed designs and printing parameters for producing the RF components with a low failure rate. By the end of this project, users will be able to design, predict, and reliably print RF components with conductive filament on low-cost 3D printers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the award period, we have accomplished the technical objectives defined in the Phase I proposal. An in-house facility was established not only for research and development of desired conductive filled polymers, facilitating the advancement of our core technology to a new performance level, but also for low-volume production of conductive pellets and filament, providing sufficient materials for internal research and customer discovery. With the new facility, we have further demonstrated several feasible approaches to produce filled conductive polymers with at least 10 times higher conductivity and operating temperature close to 150 °C. Meanwhile, we have demonstrated the feasibility of 3D fabrication of interconnected circuitry and discrete electronic and RF components, and integration with standard surface mount devices through collaborations with research institutes and industrial companies. The improvement in the material properties, leveraging with the capability of additive manufacturing of electronic and RF components from prototyping to high volume manufacturing, enables us to redefine the manufacturing of electronics. Electronic designs can be reassessed at a much higher rate compared to traditional printed circuit board technologies, therefore accelerating a company's market entry time and improved market share. The geometrical freedom unique to our additive manufacturing technology enables novel electronic design concepts paving the way as a value add reseller and new product introduction. Lastly, our electronic system technology and concepts can leverage high volume and readily available manufacturers tooling/processes therefore minimizing capex in manufacturing and supply chain operations.

In addition to the high impact to the electronics industry, Multi3D's conductive material has been instrumental in the development and understanding of metasurfaces and metamaterials. Researchers at Duke University have leveraged our conductive Electrifi filament to 3D print antenna designs to create systems that can profoundly alter the electro-magnetic properties of waves. Known as frequency-diverse imaging, this technology can span imaging applications from biomedical to security systems. Our rapid prototyping technology has enabled researchers to quickly gain fundamental theoretical understanding of the properties in this esoteric field of study.

It is envisioned that Multi3D's technology of functional electronic devices and systems can reach well beyond the commercial/military sectors and make a significant pedagogical impact in high school and university STEM programs. 3D printing has garnered tremendous interest in schools but is often limited to structural examples that have no functionality. The principal of electronics is a key component within STEM and is typically viewed as abstract to most students. This abstract nature has a steep learning curve and can lead to a high student attrition rate. Because of the electrically conductive properties of the Electrifi filament, students can leverage low-cost 3D tools to print tangible discrete to system-level electrical devices to augment their standard coursework. The end result is aimed to foster a greater appreciation and interest in the subject matter.

Untold chemical and material waste is an environmental concern. The Paris Agreement was formed to mitigate green-house gas emissions. Electronic devices from cell phones to computers use printed circuit boards or PCBs. The manufacturing process for PCBs rely on numerous chemical processes that have a deleterious effect on the environment. In addition, plastics that are used in many applications ultimately find their way as ocean waste. Our technology can efficiently reuse many of the existing plastics (i.e. biodegradable) without harmful chemicals to unleash a new disruptive approach to electronics.
